title: Submarine Lab Adventure #62
goal: Solve the puzzles, achieve the main objective, and escape.

rooms.name: Deep Sea Research Bay
rooms.description: A cramped research laboratory deep beneath the ocean surface. Water drips from corroded pipes overhead, and emergency lights cast an eerie red glow. Scientific equipment lies abandoned on metal tables. Through the reinforced porthole, you see only darkness and the occasional bioluminescent creature drifting past. The air is cold and smells of salt and rust.

items.name: research table
items.description: A stainless steel table covered with notebooks and specimen containers

items.name: research log
items.description: A waterproof notebook with detailed entries
items.text: Research Log - Deep Sea Station Nautilus, established 2089. Lead Scientist: Dr. Elena Vasquez. Chief Engineer: Marcus Webb. Our mission: study deep sea organisms at 3000 meters depth. The specimens are stored in the containment lockers.

items.name: specimen containers
items.description: Glass containers with preserved deep sea creatures

items.name: security keycard
items.description: A magnetic keycard labeled 'AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL'

items.name: storage locker
items.description: A tall metal locker with three compartments for equipment storage

items.name: station operations manual
items.description: A technical manual for the submarine lab
items.text: NAUTILUS STATION MANUAL: Established 2089 at 3000 meters depth. Emergency protocols require knowledge of key personnel and systems. The control room manages all life support and escape systems. Remember: the combination to secure storage is the year of establishment.

items.name: brass control room key
items.description: A key labeled 'CONTROL ROOM ACCESS'

items.name: research computer terminal
items.description: A computer screen displaying system status and logs
items.text: SYSTEM STATUS: Life support critical. Dr. Vasquez logged: 'Emergency evacuation may be necessary. Chief Engineer Webb has secured the escape pod bay. Only authorized personnel with proper credentials can access the pods.'

items.name: specimen containment locker
items.description: A reinforced locker with a keycard reader

items.name: emergency procedures note
items.description: A laminated card with emergency instructions
items.text: EMERGENCY EVACUATION: Proceed to control room, then escape pod bay. Security verification required at pod bay: Who leads the research? What manages life support? What is your depth?

items.name: pressure door to control room
items.description: A heavy reinforced door with a brass lock, leading to the control room

rooms.name: Central Control Room
rooms.description: The nerve center of the submarine lab. Banks of monitors display depth readings, oxygen levels, and hull integrity warnings. Red emergency lights flash rhythmically. A large viewport shows the crushing darkness of the deep ocean. Control panels line the walls, and a sealed hatch leads to the escape pod bay.

items.name: main control console
items.description: The primary control station with multiple displays and readouts
items.text: STATION STATUS: Depth: 3000 meters. Life Support: CRITICAL. Hull Integrity: 67%. Lead Scientist Dr. Elena Vasquez has authorized emergency evacuation. Control room manages all life support systems.

items.name: personnel assignment board
items.description: A digital display showing crew assignments and photos
items.text: CREW ROSTER: Dr. Elena Vasquez - Lead Scientist, Marine Biology. Marcus Webb - Chief Engineer, Life Support Systems. Station depth: 3000 meters below surface.

items.name: engineering control panel
items.description: Controls for life support and environmental systems
items.text: LIFE SUPPORT SYSTEMS: Oxygen generation: FAILING. Temperature control: NOMINAL. Pressure regulation: CRITICAL. All systems managed from control room. Chief Engineer Webb's last entry: 'Life support failing. Evacuation imminent.'

items.name: emergency equipment locker
items.description: A red locker containing emergency supplies

items.name: emergency oxygen mask
items.description: A portable breathing apparatus for emergencies

items.name: depth gauge
items.description: A device showing current depth: 3000 meters
items.text: Current depth reading: 3000 meters below sea level. Maximum safe operating depth for escape pods.

items.name: station commander's desk
items.description: A desk with logs and documentation

items.name: commander's final log
items.description: The last entry in the station log
items.text: Final Log Entry: Dr. Vasquez here. Systems failing at 3000 meters depth. I'm authorizing evacuation. The escape pod bay requires security verification. Remember: I lead this research, the control room manages life support, and we're at 3000 meters depth.

items.name: escape pod bay hatch
items.description: A sealed hatch with a security terminal displaying three verification questions. Red warning lights flash around it.

password_questions.question: Who leads the research station?
password_questions.hint: Check the research log and personnel board for the lead scientist's name

password_questions.question: What system manages life support?
password_questions.hint: The station manual and control panels mention what manages life support

password_questions.question: What is the station depth in meters?
password_questions.hint: Multiple displays and documents show the depth reading

rooms.name: Emergency Escape Pod Bay
rooms.description: You've reached the escape pod bay! A sleek emergency submersible sits in its launch cradle, its systems humming to life. Through the launch tube above, you can see the faint glow of sunlight filtering down from the surface far above. The pod's interior lights up, displaying 'LAUNCH SEQUENCE READY' on its control panel. Safety at the surface awaits!

items.name: emergency escape pod
items.description: A compact submersible designed for emergency evacuation to the surface

items.name: pod launch controls
items.description: The control panel showing all systems green and ready for launch

items.name: vertical launch tube
items.description: A tube leading upward to the ocean surface, 3000 meters above

rooms.win_message: SUCCESS! You climb into the escape pod and seal the hatch. The launch sequence initiates, and the pod rockets upward through the launch tube. The crushing darkness of the deep ocean gives way to blue water, then brilliant sunlight as you breach the surface. You've escaped the failing submarine lab and survived the depths! You win!
